STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
February 16, 2024
MATTHEW KUZMA
KALAMAZOO COUNTY DHHS
427 E Alcott St,
Kalamazoo, MI, 49001-6170
Re: License #: CP390201215
Dear MATTHEW KUZMA:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
2/5/2024-2/15/2024. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616)204-6992.
Sincerely,
Holly Austin, Licensing Consultant
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
INTERIM INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CP390201215
Licensee Group Organization: Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services
Licensee Designee: Demetrius LuJuan Starling
Chief Administrator: MATTHEW KUZMA
Name of Agency: KALAMAZOO COUNTY DHHS
Agency Address: 427 E Alcott St
Kalamazoo, MI 49001-6170
Agency Telephone #: 2693375000
Original Issuance Date: 09/10/1993
Service Types: Certify foster homes for license, Place
children in foster home, Supervise
Independent Living
1

II. METHODS OF INSPECTION
A. Consultant
Date(s) of On-site Inspection: 2/5/2024
Total No. Of No. of
Records Records
Reviewed

since last inspection 1 1

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records
• (3) The personnel record must contain both of the
following:
• (a) A written evaluation of a staff member's
performance within a probationary period or
not later than 6 months after the staff
member assumes his or her current
responsibilities. After the initial evaluation,
a written evaluation must be conducted
every 12 months.
4 of 20 employee files reviewed contained performance evaluations not completed
timely.
CPA Rule 400.12306 Application request
• (3) An agency shall provide the licensee an
application for renewal of the license and
document the action not less than 60 calendar
days before the expiration date of the license. A
renewal application must be provided to a
licensee, regardless of any pending
recommendation for disciplinary action of the
license.
2

1 of 6 open foster homes files reviewed contained documentation that a renewal
application was not provided to the family at least 60 days before license expiration.
CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement
• (3) The agency shall document all the following in
the child's record before a change of placement
occurs:
• (f) Notification to the parents, referral
source, lawyer guardian ad litem, and
courts when applicable, of the change in
placement.
1 of 8 open files of youth in foster care placements did not contain documentation
that all required notifications of placement change were made for 2 consecutive
placement changes.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal 2/7/2023, CAP Approved 2/22/2023.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
• (2) An agency shall complete written service plans
for each child and parent or parents, as follows:
• (a) Within 30 calendar days from removal
from the home.
1 of 11 open youth files reviewed (8 foster care & 3 IL) contained an initial service
plan not completed timely. This represented 1 of 4 initial service plans reviewed.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal 2/7/2023, CAP Approved 2/22/2023.
Renewal 9/8/2022, CAP Approved 9/23/2022.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
• (2) An agency shall complete written service plans
for each child and parent or parents, as follows:
3

• (b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial
removal and at least once every 90
calendar days thereafter.
2 of 11 open youth files reviewed (8 foster care & 3 IL) contained updated service
plans not completed timely. This represented 2 of 34 updated service plans
reviewed.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal 2/7/2023, CAP Approved 2/22/2023.
Renewal 9/8/2022, CAP Approved 9/23/2022.
CPA Rule 400.12421 Visitation and family time; in person contact
• (2) An agency social service worker shall visit the
foster child, and the foster parent, if applicable, in
the child's placement at least once every month.
1 of 8 open files of youth in foster care placements did not contain documentation
that required face to face visits with the youth and caregiver in the caregiver's home
was conducted in February of 2023. It is noted this case is an ICPC case and those
visits are being conducted by an out of state agency; however, the local office is
responsible for ensuring the visits occur and are documented.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Previously cited as 400.12421(b), Renewal 2/7/2023, CAP Approved 2/22/2023.
Previously cited as FOM 722-06H, Renewal 9/8/2022, CAP Approved 9/23/2022.
CPA Rule 400.12505 Supervision
• (2) An agency shall provide the following minimum
supervision:
• (a) Face-to-face contact between the social
service worker and the youth in
independent living at least once each
month at a youth's place of residence.
2 of 3 open files of youth in independent living placements did not contain
documentation that all required face to face visits with the youth in their homes were
completed. Both files were missing visits documented for January of 2024.
CPA Rule 400.12505 Supervision
4

• (2) An agency shall provide the following minimum
supervision:
• (b) At monthly intervals, ensure that the
youth is complying with the terms of the
required by R 400.12510, continues to
reside in a safe and acceptable
environment, and is managing
expenditures.
1 of 3 open files of youth in independent living placements did not contain
documentation that monthly compliance with the term of the independent living
contract were assessed in January of 2024.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal 9/8/2022, CAP Approved 9/23/2022.
FOM 722-06B Family Team Meeting
FTMs must occur within the required time frames as
outlined in the following tables:
Case Plan Development/ Reassessment Initial Case
Plan (ISP) - within 30 calendar days before the case plan
due date. Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar
days before the case plan due date.
Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) - within 30
calendar days before the case plan due date.
Placement Preservation/ Disruption At least three
business days prior to a planned change of placement or
no later than three business days after an unplanned
placement change.
Case Closure Within 30 calendar days before the case
closure date or one business day after unplanned court
ordered dismissal.
Documentation The DHS-1105, Family Team Meeting
Report, is used to capture family demographics, FTM
logistical information, needs, strengths, action steps,
safety concerns and the safety plan, and any
recommendations made for the family during the FTM.
5

The DHS-1105, FTM Report, must be completed for
every FTM.
The caseworker must enter the FTM information in
MiSACWIS using the FTM hyperlink within 7 business
days of the FTM.
4 of 11 open youth files reviewed (8 foster care & 3 IL) did not meet all FTM
requirements. Four files did not have all required FTMs documented. Four files did
not contain all paperwork required for FTMS documented to have been held.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal 2/7/2023, CAP Approved 2/22/2023.
Renewal 9/8/2022, CAP Approved 9/23/2022.
FOM 722-08D TREATMENT PLANS - AGREEMENT AND
S IGNATURES
Once completed and approved, the caseworker must
obtain signatures from the following individuals, as
applicable:
• Caseworker
• Supervisor
• Second line supervisor, when siblings in care are
placed apart
• Parents who are a member of a participating
household.
• Youth ages 14 and older.
• Foster parents, relative caregivers, and unrelated
court-ordered caregivers.
Parents/legal guardians, youth, and caregivers must
check yes or no for the following when signing the
treatment plan:
• I have participated in the development of the
Case Service Plan and the Parent Agency
Treatment Plan.
• I agree with the Case Service Plan and Parent
Agency Treatment Plan.
• I have been provided a copy of the Case Service
Plan and Parent Agency Treatment Plan to
review, and I will have the opportunity to express
my disagreement with the Case Service Plan and
Parent Agency Treatment Plan when the
information is presented to court.
6

Note: If a parent or youth is unavailable or refuses to
sign the treatment plan, the caseworker must identify,
and document actions needed to secure the parent’s
and/or youth’s participation in service planning and
compliance with the treatment plan.
The caseworker must obtain signatures from all applicable
individuals and upload the signatures pages into the
electronic case record within 30 days of the report date.
8 of 11 open youth files reviewed (8 foster care & 3 IL) contained PATPs either missing
required signatures or had signatures documented to have been obtained past the 30-day
requirement. This violation is present in 25 of 38 PATPs reviewed.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal 2/7/2023, CAP Approved 2/22/2023.
Renewal 9/8/2022, CAP Approved 9/23/2022
F OM 801-03 M EDICAL PASSPORT
For children entering foster care, the initial medical
passport must be provided within two weeks of the
child's placement date to the following: • Foster care
provider. • Young adult voluntary foster care (YAVFC)
youth/young adult re-entering foster care. The actual
date the medical passport is provided must be
documented in the electronic case management record.
Note: Foster care provider includes foster homes,
shelter, adult foster home, fictive kin, relative
placements, detention, and residential facilities.
All medical information within the medical passport
must be current and updated at least quarterly to
reflect the child's current and complete health
information.
Each caseworker who transfers a child's medical
passport to another caseworker must sign and date the
medical passport verifying that they have sought and
obtained the necessary information under law and
Michigan Department of Health and Human Services
(MDHHS) policy.
An updated medical passport is provided to:
• Participating legal parents if the child is a temporary
court ward. Quarterly, while in out-of-home placement. At
7

reunification. Subsequent medical passports are not
required after reunification. Non-offending parent,
subsequent medical passports are not required after
reunification.
• The child’s foster care provider at or prior to each
placement. Note: Non-offending parent with custody of
the child is not considered a foster parent placement.
• All medical and mental health professionals to whom
the child is newly referred to and accepted for treatment
or services prior to or at the first scheduled appointment
while the foster care case is open, regardless of
placement. Subsequent medical passports are not
required.
• Older youth/young adults: Upon initial independent
living placement (youth aged 16 and over). Upon exiting
the foster care system (young adults aged 18 and older)
Receipt of the medical passport by the above listed
parties is documented in the electronic case
management record by uploading the signed and
dated signature page into the Health Profile section.
2 of 11 open youth files reviewed (8 foster care & 3 IL) did not contain documentation that
all medical passport signature requirements were met timely.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal 2/7/2023, CAP Approved 2/22/2023.
Renewal 9/8/2022, CAP Approved 9/23/2022.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Service plans should be signed by the worker and supervisor and
uploaded into the case record upon approval to avoid missing signatures due to
workers or supervisors no longer being with the agency at the time the document
is uploaded.
• When reviewing service plans, supervisors must review case contacts to
ensure face to face visits are occurring with the youth and caregiver and that
quality contacts are occurring and that all case contacts are entered prior to
approving the service plan. This will assist the supervisors in ensuring visits are
not being missed and/or that visits being supervised by courtesy/ICPC worker
are occurring and being documented.
V. CONSULTATION
8

The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• Review with staff responsible for uploading documents where those
documents are to be uploaded to avoid documents being placed in incorrect
locations or being uploaded to multiple locations.
• Reminder that all renewal/annual foster home evaluation reports must be
completed within 1 year from the date of the previous evaluation report (in
addition to being completed at least 15 days prior to license interim/expiration
date.) EXAMPLE: If a license expiration date 4/1/25, the annual reevaluation
report is due no later than 3/18/24. Additionally, if the previous reevaluation
report was completed 3/5/23, the 2024 reevaluation report must be completed no
later than 3/5/24. Also, home visits conducted for foster home reevaluation must
be made within 1 year of the date of the previous year's home visit.
VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There was 1 incident of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period. The one Special Evaluation Report addressing a corporal punishment was
reviewed. The report was completed timely and thoroughly.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plan (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows. In 2023,
the agency submitted a CAP to address 12 violation. This year's inspection will
require the agency to submit a CAP to address 11 violation. Of those 11
violations, 7 are repeated violations previously addressed in the 2023 CAP. There
has been an increase in number of files effected in 1 of those violations, a
decrease in number of files effected in 4 of those violations, and the number of
individual incidents remained the same in the 2 remaining violations. Additionally,
7 of the violations cited during this inspection were previously addressed in the
2022 CAP. Three violations established during this inspection have not been
established during the previous two inspections. There has been an improvement
in overall number of citations and individual incidents of non-compliance over the
past 3 years. The agency staff continue to need improvement when it comes to
obtaining and uploading signatures timely on required documentation.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The chief administrator assessment indicated there has been an increase in
staffing over the past year which has resulted in caseworkers being able to stay
within caseload compliance. New staff members have resulted in periods of
learning during which non-compliances have occurred. Additionally, there was
recognition that some of the compliance monitoring methods put into place after
9

the last inspection were not effective. The agency staff are currently working to
implement new methods of compliance monitoring.
Financial Overview
N/A
Staff Interviews
The staff members interviewed indicated that the increase in staffing and reduction
in caseload sizes has improved their ability to perform the job requirements as well
as increasing their motivation and overall morale. They all indicated that their
direct supervisors are accessible, supportive, and helpful in completing required
tasks. Additionally, they all stated that upper management has involved the staff in
discussions regarding improving compliance resulting in the staff members'
thoughts and ideas being incorporated into compliance monitoring.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency has the space and equipment needed for staff members to complete
required job responsibilities. Foster care, adoption, independent living, and
certification files are securely stored in a locked file storage room that requires key
card entry. Physical CHRI is stored in a locked cabinet in the Director's office and
the key is held by the licensing supervisor.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
The DCWL Analyst identified 1 safety concern as follows:
Safety Alert: The DCWL Analyst was unable to assess the safety of the home due
to the family not responding to multiple contact attempts.
Resolution: A DHHS staff member visited the home on 11/16/23. Safety was
assessed and documented by that worker.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
10

February 15, 2024

Holly Austin Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
